a farmer in Uganda.“Once they land in your garden they do total destruction. Some people will even tell you that the locusts are more destructive than the coronavirus. There are even some who don’t believe that the virus will reach here.”Some farmers in Mr Abokat’s village near the Kenyan border bang metal pans, whistle or throw stones to try to drive the locusts away. But mostly they watch in frustration, largely barred by a coronavirus lockdown from gathering outside their homes.A failed garden of cassava, a local staple, means hunger. Such worries in the village of some 600 people are reflected across a large part of East Africa, including Kenya, Ethiopia and South Sudan. The locust swarms also have been sighted in Djibouti, Eritrea, Tanzania and Congo.The UN&nbspFood and Agriculture Organisation&nbsp(FAO) has called the locust outbreak, caused in part by climate change, “an unprecedented threat” to food security and livelihoods. Its officials have called this new wave some 20 times the size of the first.Army of 100,000 ducks deployed to combat locust infestationLocust swarms cross into hunger-hit South Sudan‘Catastrophe’: Biggest locust swarm in decades triggers dire warning“The current situation in East Africa remains extremely alarming as ... an increasing number of new swarms are forming in Kenya, southern Ethiopia and Somalia,” a new FAO assessment said.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailFavourable breeding conditions through May mean there likely will be another new round of swarms in late June and July, coinciding with the start of the harvest season, the agency said.The UN&nbsphas raised its aid appeal from $76m (£61m) to $153m, saying immediate action is needed before more rainfall fuels further growth in locust numbers. So far the FAO has collected $111m&nbspin cash or pledges.The locusts are “invading the Eastern Africa region in exceptionally large swarms like never seen before”,&nbspthe Nairobi-based Climate Prediction and Application Centre said.The new swarms include “young adults”,&nbspvoracious bugs “that eat more than the adult ones”,&nbspsaid Kenneth Mwangi, a satellite information analyst at the centre.Mr Mwangi and other officials in Kenya cited difficulties in fighting the infestation as coronavirus-related travel restrictions slow cross-border travel and delay the delivery of pesticides.The verification work of field officers has been curtailed, making it harder for the centre to update regional prediction models, Mr Mwangi said.In rural Laikipia county, among the worst affected in Kenya, some are calling attention to the threat to commercial farms.“I think, unfortunately, because of other things going on around the world, people are forgetting about the problem with the locusts. But it’s a very, very real problem,” farmer George Dodds told the FAO.Aerial spraying is the only effective way to control the locust outbreak. After the locusts crossed into Uganda for the first time since the 1960s, soldiers resorted to using hand-held spray pumps because of difficulties in obtaining the needed aircraft.Uganda’s agriculture minister said authorities are unable to import enough pesticides from Japan, citing disruptions to international cargo shipments.The government is yet to meet an additional budget of over $4m requested for locust control, the minister said.The sum is substantial in a country where the president has been fundraising from wealthy people to help respond to the virus and its economic disruption. Health workers are threatening to strike over lack of protective gear.In Ethiopia, where some 6 million people live in areas affected by the locust outbreak, the infestation if unchecked “will cause large-scale crop, pasture and forest-cover loss, worsening food and feed insecurity”,&nbspthe FAO says.Bands of immature locusts are forming in areas that include the country’s breadbasket, the Rift Valley region, it said.Ethiopia’s agriculture minister has said efforts are under way to deploy six helicopters against the infestation that could last until late August.But ministry spokesman Moges Hailu spoke of an ominous sign: the locust swarms are now appearing in locations where they had not been previously sighted.Additional reporting by APShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - They will be offered positions based on seniority, the union said.Tracking the coronavirus outbreak around the world in maps and chartsWhen can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsListen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastDisney World is expected to furlough up to 77,000 workers in all. The Orlando Sentinel reports that adding that number to unemployment figures would triple the city's jobless rate from 2.9 per cent in February to 8.5 per cent.Sean Snaith, an economist at the University of Central Florida, told the paper that the move would have a knock-on effect for the area's airport and car rental companies.He said: All the suppliers that will normally actively be engaged with Disney have gone idle as well.In a statement the company said: The Covid-19 pandemic is having a devastating impact on our world with untold suffering and loss, and has required all of us to make sacrifices. title: coronavirus sun bears china medicine wildlife trade malaysia poachers
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘Desperate consumers may easily be swayed,’ conservation experts warnThreatened&nbspsun bears could suffer from increased poaching due to the Chinese government’s touting of discredited bear bile treatment for coronavirus, conservation charities&nbsphave warned.In a list of recommended treatments for Covid-19 published last month, China’s National Health Commission promoted injections of a “traditional medicine” containing bear bile.An estimated 12,000 bears are held in captivity on farms in China and Vietnam, where they are “milked” for the digestive fluid.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesBut experts said&nbspChina’s official approval of the so-called medicine could influence “desperate” consumers in Malaysia, potentially leading to an increase in sun bear poaching there.Monitor, a conservation society dedicated to lesser-known species, said the&nbspbear, which is found in tropical forests across Southeast Asia,&nbspwas already threatened with extinction.“Desperate consumers may easily be swayed,” Monitor spokesperson Loretta Shepherd told Free Malaysia Today&nbsp(FMT). “There is a very real chance that our sun bears will be at increased risk. We could see an increase in the use of bear bile medicine and a rise in the poaching of sun bears.”Tracking the coronavirus outbreak around the world in maps and chartsWhen can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsListen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastAccording to a study last year by Traffic, an organisation tackling the international wildlife trade, illegal trade in bear parts in Malaysia had increased since 2015.It reported bear-based medicines were on offer in more than two-thirds of traditional Chinese medicine shops in the country.Andrew Sebastian, head of the Malaysian Ecotourism and Conservation Society, told FMT China’s message would increase the demand for bear bile in China itself as well as Malaysia.Bear bile is an ingredient of “tan re qing”, injections of which are among recommended treatments for severe and critical coronavirus patients in a plan published three weeks ago, circulated by Chinese state media.In February, the Chinese government banned the eating and transport for eating of wild animals as coronavirus was spreading, but it did not cover use of wildlife products in Chinese medicine or as ornamental items.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus china food meat market seafood
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Stop the Wildlife Trade: In February, China passed a law to outlaw all wildlife trade and consumption, but despite the government’s efforts to weed out the possible source of the coronavirus outbreak, markets remain open across the countryCordoned off by blue barricades and police lines, the once-bustling Huanan Seafood Market has suspended operation since 1 January, after dozens of customers fell ill to what we now know as the deadly&nbspCovid-19&nbspvirus. The sign that adorned the entrance of the market, a landmark of Wuhan city, has also been removed.As residents prepare for a return to work this week, business owners at the market will have nowhere to go. “Since all businesses need to apply for permission from the government before they restart operation, it will be impossible for these businesses to gain the government’s approval,” said Michael, who used to own a fruit stand a few blocks away from the Huanan Seafood Market and refused to give his real name.Wildlife trade was once a lucrative and thriving industry in China, but the suspicion that the current coronavirus pandemic started in&nbspexotic animals smuggled into the country has forced the government to crack down on the decades-old trade.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesLast month, Beijing rolled out a strict ban on the breeding and consumption of wild animals, as it tried to prevent another outbreak from happening. This was a general guidance issued from the central government, with the power to enforce the law ultimately lying with provincial or municipal officials.Several other provinces have followed suit, and the southern industrial hub Shenzhen announced a ban on the sale and consumption of dog and cat meat on Thursday, becoming the first Chinese city to do so.When can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?Listen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastIn Wuhan, local officials have been increasingly strict in their crackdown on businesses engaged in wildlife trade or breeding. On 3 March, local authorities in Wuhan carried out a comprehensive disinfection campaign across the entire Huanan Seafood Market.However, recent reports suggest that despite the regional governments'&nbspefforts to put an end to wildlife trade, illicit commercial activities are still happening at public markets in certain parts of China. Earlier this week, the Mail on Sunday reported that thousands of customers flooded an indoor market in the southwestern city of Guilin in China, as living dogs and cats were crammed into cages while dead bats and scorpions were on display.Andrew Huang, a Chinese culinary expert, says one of the reasons why it’s hard for the Chinese government to completely end the consumption and trading of wildlife in China is because such behaviours have become part of decades-olds tradition in the country.“Different parts of China have their specific traditions of consuming wildlife for different purposes,” Mr Huang explains. “In the northeastern part of China, bears and deers are a big part of the local delicacies while in southwestern China, bats and pangolins are often used in traditional Chinese medicine. The steady demand for such wildlife has nurtured a lucrative supply chain, including some businesses that focus on breeding specific types of wild animals.”Mr Huang thinks that the current crackdown on wildlife trade and consumption might temporarily prevent relevant practices from happening in public markets, but it will be hard to completely eliminate it from the Chinese culture.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Even if the government has banned wildlife trade and consumption, the tradition won’t be so easily wiped out.”‘No need to close the entire market’In Wuhan, while the plan to shut down the Huanan Seafood Market is underway, local residents have different opinions about how to handle the market where the coronavirus pandemic began.“Honestly, wildlife trade isn’t the main commercial activity at the Hunan Seafood Market, as most of the sellers still focus on selling different kinds of seafood,” says Ms Xu, who was a frequent shopper at the market until it was shut down.Since the market is right next to one of the major train stations in the city, she says, it has become the regional hub for selling fruits and seafood, as well as wildlife. Due to the large number of visitors coming from different parts of Hubei province, it also became the ideal breeding ground for the coronavirus.“I think even if the government wants to ban wildlife trade, they don’t have to shut down the entire seafood market,” Ms Xu says. “This will have a huge impact on local restaurants and businesses that have long relied on the market for their seafood supplies.”Ms Xu says that instead of forcing dozens of business owners to lose their livelihoods, the Chinese government should focus more on tackling the ongoing pandemic itself. “I wish the government could conduct more coronavirus tests on citizens, because I suspect many of them could still be asymptomatic patients or patients with mild symptoms,” she said.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: cautiously safely kids back to school
story: THE question of when and how we re-open our schools is one of the key issues the nation will face when it steps carefully away from this Covid- lockdown.Based on the evidence, I believe that re-opening schools should be considered early in the exit strategy because it appears they play a relatively small role in transmissions.We tend to see children as excellent spreaders of bugs, and therefore ­closing schools seems to make sense.Yet research published earlier this week shows that this isn’t necessarily true for the Covid- virus.Almost everything we know about closing schools to stop disease outbreaks comes from influenza.Flu is a very dferent virus to coronavirus, and children drive much of influenza’s transmission.Coronavirus is less likely to affect children and young people.They rarely get very sick, and they mostly get very mild symptoms or show no ­symptoms at all.During the  epidemic caused by Sars — a cousin of Covid- — the data showed that schools and schoolchildren played no role in transmitting the virus.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here. The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealClosing schools harms our children in many ways.Yes, many of them are getting some online teaching  —  my -year-old had brilliant support from his school before the holidays.But we know that some schools are offering much less, and I worry that it is particularly the poorest children who are ­missing out.Children also benefit from school through contact with friends and adults outside their family.Plus there is support for mental health and even in the food that they might not get at home.School closures also force children together with parents at home for weeks on end.This can be a source of great bonding, but we know that, particularly for teens, being cut off from peer groups and other adults is not good for their development or mental health.The issue of forcing key worker parents to stay home has been largely solved during the pandemic by keeping some schools open just for their ­children.But for parents who are not key workers, being forced to look after ­children for weeks at home can prevent them earning an income.Closing schools has in the past been shown to increase social contacts between children outside school, and between children and adults looking after them, particularly grandparents, who are most vulnerable to this virus.Currently, those over  should be self- isolating away from children.But there are many grandparents who are under .Andschools stay closed while we allow adults to exit lockdown first, we risk an increase in contact between children and grandparents.One of the problems is that we tend to think of schools as being entirely closed or open.Our research showed that there are a range of potential options.It would mean a partial or staged re-opening with social distancing built in.The point of social distancing for schools is to reduce the number of children in contact at any one time.Ensuring that dferent school years don’t meet would be a useful start.So have half the school attend in the morning and half in the afternoon, close the playgrounds and stagger year-group start, end and break times so that ­dferent years never meet.Then ensure that dferent classes don’t meet.This could mean staggering start times by class or alternating the ways that classes enter and leave school, and ­keeping students in form classes for all their lessons.Schools could also look at how feasible social distancing is within classes.True, most British classrooms could not fit a metre between desks.However,only half of the school is attending at any one time, classes could spread out across more than one classroom.We also need very clear rules on when not to come to school with any ­symptoms, and the need for self-isolation at homeothers in the family had been ill will be required.Teachers need to be protected, as we protect those who ­continue to drive buses, man shopping centres and work in our health ­system.And teachers should be early in the queue for testing.This may all sound too dficult.However, we owe it to our ­children to examine all of these options.It could be done more easilywe had sufficient testing to know which children or teachers had had Covid-.But we may need to proceed ­without that, given what we are currently told about antibody-testing timescales.As mentioned, our schools are already ­partially open — for the children of key workers and vulnerable children.Let’s gradually increase that “partially” in a way that’s guided by science.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: krakatoa volcano erupts ash
story: Two eruptions were recorded by the countrys volcanology centre last night between .pm and .pm local time. Residents of Indonesia’s capital Jakarta — more than  miles away — reportedly heard loud thunder-like sounds after the eruptions. A resident on Sebesi Island, which is  miles away from Krakatoa, told local media that thick ash started to drop in front of his home after the eruptions.Some took to Twitter to share what they heard.One joked: We are fighting coronavirus. Please, go to sleep.Another said: Guys I just want to let you know that mount Krakatoa is erupting [right now], I keep hearing noises here in Indonesia.The eruption is believed to be the biggest since the partial collapse of the volcano in December  which unleashed a tsunami that killed more than  people.No wave was reported this time. Following its collapse in , the volcano lost about two-thirds of its height and three-quarters of its mass. But Krakatoa’s eruption in August  was the worst and in fact the most deadly in modern history, killing about , people.The Volcanology and Geological Hazard Mitigation Centeralso confirmed that three other volcanoes in Indonesia erupted last night.But they are unrelated as each volcano had a dferent magma chamber.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gordon taylor ruined footballers reputation coronavirus
story: WE live in an age of heroes – when every day brings acts of kindness, courage and humanity that shine like a light among the darkness.The nation unites every Thursday night at pm to applaud the doctors, nurses and carers who put their lives on the line every time they go to work.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updates But there are other unsung heroes, working in low-paid jobs, that leave them exposed while the rest of us are safe at home.I think of the cleaners who go into those hospitals every day.Our bin men are heroes, too. And the bus drivers — nine already dead in London alone from Covid-. And the pharmacists filling out prescriptions in tiny, windowless shops.And the postmen, delivery drivers, papergirls — and anonymous neighbours who put notes through doors offering help for the vulnerable.And the supermarket workers who stack the shelves to keep our nation fed. And a round of applause for our Queen,  this month, who gave the speech of a letime last Sunday — and for our Prime Minister who ended up in intensive care.From the bin men to Boris, we are surrounded by heroes — but the one glaring exception has been elite football.Despite inidual acts of heroism, such as Manchester United’s Marcus Rashford raising £million for underprivileged schoolkids, football has not covered itself in glory during this national emergency.On Wednesday, Premier League captains announced they were banding together to create a fund to raise millions for the NHS.This is a big-hearted gesture but can’t hide the fact that for much of this health crisis the national game has been hopelessly out of touch with the national mood.When the Prime Minister was seriously ill, it made the skin crawl to see whining millionaire footballers resisting pay cuts from clubs that have nothing to sell, no revenue coming in and no idea when football will begin again.Gordon Taylor, the £million-a-year chief of the Professional Footballers Association, has made his members about as popular as bankers.While the country fights for its le, Taylor has fought for the rights of loafing footballers to keep every last million. He has badly misjudged the moment, as have the clubs owned by billionaires who have furloughed their tea ladies while pampered footballers continue to earn up to £, a week.It has been embarrassing to see hypocritical footballers mistaking “lockdown” for “lock-in”, acting like the new rules do not apply to them.After previously urging fans to stay at home, Aston Villa’s Jack Grealish emerged bleary-eyed from an all-night party and pranged his -grand Range Rover.Manchester City’s Kyle Walker had a couple of escort girls delivered to his door, soon before telling the peasants to social distance and save lives and blah-blah-blah. All that stuff about washing your hands, Kyle — should that be before or after the escorts have been round And Spurs manager Jose Mourinho oversaw a training session on Hadley Common, for all the world asthere was one rule for the princes of football and one for the plebs who pay their wages.Do the fatheads of football ever watch the news Mass unemployment is coming. Many of the millions about to be chucked on the dole will be football fans. So how the hell can football — the players, clubs, PFA — continue to kid themselves the bubble they exist in has not already burst The world has changed.There should be no more all-night parties, no more escort girls and no more car prangs. Like it or not, footballers are role models and many will follow their lead.Troy Deeney, Watford captain and one of the prime movers behind the Players Together fund, defends Jack Grealish’s busy social le during the time of lockdown. “What’s he going to do ” Troy asked. “Sit in the yard on his own ”Yes, Troy — because that’s what millions are doing right now. Shocking, I know, but the new rules apply to footballers, too.Most footballers come from working-class backgrounds but too many of them have a sense of entitlement worthy of Marie Antoinette.Look what happened to her.NEVER going out is placing an unbearable strain on relationships.So it is nice to see that Camila Morrone, , and Leonardo DiCaprio, , seem to be happily self-isolating together.I was afraid Leo might decide Camila’s just too old for him.STEVE HEDLEY, rail union fat cat at the RMT, boasts that he would “throw a party”Boris Johnson died of coronavirus – and hopes “the whole Cabinet of Tory b******s” also become victims.If Hedley was on a ventilator fighting for his le, would he check how the doctors and nurses caring for him voted at the last election You don’t think those NHS heroes all voted Labour, do you, Steve WILLIAM and Kate carried out their first virtual royal duty this week, thanking teaching staff who look after the children of key workers.I have never seen smiles that wide on the faces of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge.I am sure that, deep down inside, they are really missing Harry and Meghan.They are just covering it up really well.FAREWELL Honor Blackman, who has died at the age of , immortal for ever in her career-defining role as Pussy Galore in Goldfinger.It is funny how certain names fall out of favour.At school I had mates called Keith and Ian, but nobody is called Keith or Ian today.Same thing with Pussy Galore. Bond girls just don’t get called things like Pussy Galore any more.THIS lockdown is taking an enormous toll on jobs, education and mental health but most of us understand it is necessary.I am infuriated, though, by the constant threats to intensy the lockdown, including closing the parks,a handful of idiots continue to flout the rules.Health Secretary Matt Hancock rages that he finds it “unbelievable that people are not staying at home” – and threatens to ban all exercise.Personally, I find it unbelievable that Hancock makes threats like some little home counties Hitler.Give credit to the MILLIONS who are doing their best during the lockdown.Don’t threaten the decent majority with a punishment beating because a selfish minority break the rules.If this Government ramps up the lockdown they will lose the British people. And something will explode.If some morons can’t stick to the rules, punish THEM – not the rest of us.KILLING EVE lost its way when the show’s creator Phoebe “Fleabag” Waller-Bridge bailed out after the first series. The second series was painfully naff.Early reports on the third series, starting tomorrow on BBC iPlayer, are not promising.But Jodie Comer as Russian assassin Villanelle will always make you want to tune in. Evenit is just for her new outfits.THIS global catastrophe started in China.When the dead are buried and we stand among our ruined economies, there MUST be some kind of reckoning.After World War Two, the Potsdam Conference decided that Germany should pay billion for what Germany had inflicted on humanity.China is now boasting that le is back to normal there, while we are burying NHS nurses like Rebecca Mack, , who worked in a children’s cancer unit. She has been hailed as a “wonderful daughter” by her heartbroken parents.Coronavirus was not an act of God. It started in China.A study by  senior Tories concludes that the UK should pursue China through international courts for £billion in coronavirus compensation.Germany paid for starting the war. Why shouldn’t China pay for coronavirus GREAT news that Boris is out of intensive care and on the way to recovery.But when he emerges from that ICU, he must give himself all the time it takes to fully recover.And then Boris has to lose weight. I saw David Cameron describe Boris as “very fit”.Sorry – a -year-old man who weighs over st is emphatically not “very fit”.He is a serious illness – a heart attack, stroke or diabetes – waiting to happen.I know from having Boris as my neighbour for years that he loves his jogging and cycling. But please slim down, Boris.Carrie and your unborn child need you. So does Dilyn the dog. So does your country.Because Boris Johnson’s great genius is for giving people HOPE.God knows we need some of that right now. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady take responsibility lockdown
story: My goodness, aren’t we lucky to have the Queen, whose speech last Sunday was pitch-perfect. It was a magnicent address, from a magnicent woman.Her experience and serenity did more to calm and inspire the nation than anything  I can think of as this crisis has unfolded.Best of all, she reminded us that there will be le beyond this lockdown — that we will meet again.If we just focus on the here and now, we won’t be able to prepare for the future beyond the virus.But it’s also true that none of us can think straight when we are in the eye of the storm.That is where good leadership comes in. It helps us all to hold strong, not to go to pieces and to stick to the guidance given to us.Everyone looks to the leader to make decisions, and it’s the decisions we make that will chart our way out of the crisis.Unfortunately, after the Queen’s address to the nation came the news that Prime Minister Boris Johnson had been admitted to hospital intensive care.At that point, anyone who was in any doubt this illness did not discriminate was forced to reconsider.At the time of writing, Boris was back on a regular hospital ward. But his illness has been a reminder that any of us are susceptible to Covid-.Most people are shocked he is in hospital and sympathise with his pregnant girlfriend Carrie Symonds.But of course it has raised the question: Who is really in chargehe is not  Without leadership, we all get distinctly uneasy.We all have leaders in our lives. We are all looking towards them to show us what to do and lead us through it.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealSome companies have stepped up to the plate and are doing good things — reassuring their staff, treating people well and doing their utmost to make sure people will be paid. Some aren’t, of course. But good bosses are taking pay cuts and doing everything they can to keep their businesses alive and look after their staff.At West Ham United we continue to pay all our full and part-time staff  per cent of their wages.My financial director, my manager and I have all taken a  per cent reduction to make sure this happens.It’s when there’s a crisis like this that we see who is made of what.Boris’s temporary stand-in, Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab, while talking about the PM’s hospital admission, referred to him as his boss, his colleague, but also his friend.Respect and friendship are the key words when it comes to good leadership.A good leader makes the tough decisions because they are right, but they are also governed by ethics. They want to do the right thing, for the right reasons. They are happy to make personal sacrices to ensure the majority are looked after.It is more important now, than ever, to put people before profits.After three weeks of lockdown, with no chance of a let-up, it’s all too easy to fall prey to catastrophic, even apocalyptic thinking.But we have to sht our thought process. We have to accept and understand that, at some point, this WILL be over.When things are calmer and clearer, we can ask what we can do to ensure we are still operating as the world gets back to normal — whatever the new normal is.The experience we are all living through really is like a storm, which continues to rage.There are so many unprecedented aspects to this situation and there is not one person in the world who will come out of it unchanged.So while there are so many challenging and dficult things going on, perhaps this lockdown is a chance for us all to learn more about ourselves.How are you responding  Have you thought about how you can help others  Have you thought about volunteering for the NHS As well as the importance of good leadership, we all have our inidual roles when it comes to showing autonomy and courage about our own decisions.I’m sorry to say, things are going to get a lot worse before they get better.So we all need to take responsibility — or we will never get out of lockdown.ANYONE who saw the social media video of Naomi Watts reaching breaking point after her printer, vacuum cleaner and dishwasher all broke down will surely have smiled in recognition.Naomi, who has been self-isolating in her Los Angeles home for three weeks, shared her very understandable anguish with a slow-motion video of herself screaming with the sound of a lion’s roar played in the background.I think we can all relate to her frustration.My lockdown revelation I am happy to report that I have given up ironing!WHEN it comes to illness, particularly cancer, I’ve long resisted all the talk of going into battle – mainly because of the unhelpful implication of weakness among those who “lose” that fight by dying.I feel the same way about descriptions of people “fighting” coronavirus.Illness is a fact of le. It is not a sign of weakness.The sad and terrible truth is that some people get this virus and others do not.Some have it very badly – a whole lot worse than others.We don’t yet know exactly why. We don’t even knowwe have the virus and may infect people.We don’t knowthere are antibodies that can protect us from getting it again, or how long that will take.We don’t knowthere will be a more deadly mutation of the same virus in the future.There is just too much we don’t know.But there are some practical things we can do.We need to help those who have it now, and the NHS and the Government are doing all they can in this regard.We also need to stop the spread of the virus, through testing. Hopefully that is going to happen soon.Meanwhile, scientists are also working around the clock to create a vaccine.Perhaps, most of all, we need to prepare for the possibility that this could all happen again.We need to learn lessons on food distribution, working from home, adapting our businesses – and having proper personal protection and hospital equipment ready and waiting.AS time ticks on, we are all realising what le is like without the things we used to consider necessities.Like our hairdressers.Claudia Winkleman’s Instagram post showing how unmanageable her fringe has become during lockdown made me laugh in recognition.My hair is grey, long and unkempt.On the one hand, it’s the least of my worries, which is quite liberating.Still, I did manage to get my hands on some hair dye for the roots.Do I care that it’s completely the wrong shade NO. I do not.So please, can we all just agree to turn a blind eye to the way we look when we finally emerge from lockdown HAPPY Easter Sunday, people. How will you be spending yours Personally, I have lost track of what day it is. The past few weeks have been a blur, with every day feeling like a cross between Sunday and Monday.It was my birthday last week and, without loved ones to hug, friends to see, drinks to be had, it was more or less just another day.Equally, this is the first time ever that Easter has felt like just another weekend.But I hope you can find ways to make it special. Just make sure you do so at home.THERE has been talk of schools possibly reopening after the Easter holidays – and who knows whether or not that is true But one thing I do know is that, whenever they do reopen, working parents will not only give the most massive sigh of relief, they will all be thanking their children’s teachers profusely for everything that they do.We will all also be thanking doctors, nurses, all NHS employees, as well as bin men, cleaners, shop assistants and all the other key workers we have under-paid and taken for granted.I really hope that is one thing which changes as a result of this pandemic.These people are the backbone of our country.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lift coronavirus lockdown debate
story: HAVING been in lockdown for almost three weeks now, the question on everyones lips is when we can go back to our ordinary lives andto normality.We asked two experts to debate the issue. One says that restrictions should be lted sooner rather than later to reboot our ecomony, while the other argues that the restrictions are working, so now is not the right time to lt them.When Chancellor Rishi Sunak first announced his bail-out plan last month, it was estimated that ten to  per cent of workers in the ­private sector would need Government support.Now economic forecasters believe it could be a third of the total private sector workforce. That will cost the British taxpayer between £billion and £billion every three months.To date, about a fth of small businesses have been pushed into bankruptcy. If the lockdown continues to July, that figure will rise to a third.The effect of this on the economy will be catastrophic. According to the ­Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Britain’s GDP could contract by  per cent over the next two years. It shrank by six per cent during the global financial crisis of -.The Centre for Economics and Business Researchsays the lockdown is costing £.billion a day.Given we are now  days into the lockdown, this means we are already more than £billlion out of pocket.In short,we don’t ease off on the social distancing measures and re-boot the economy, we’re heading for the biggest economic downturn since the s.Against this, we are told thatwe end the lockdown more people will become infected, demand for critical hospital care will outstrip the NHS’s capacity and we’ll begin to see people dying in even greater numbers.I’m sceptical about that prognosis.It is based on the statistical modelling of Professor Neil Ferguson and his team at Imperial College, but there is mounting evidence that they under-estimated the percentage of the population already infected with coronavirus and over-estimated how deadly this disease is.According to Prof Ferguson’s model, fewer than five per cent of people have been infected. But according to another model, this one produced by Oxford University, it could be higher than  per cent, which would mean we are on our way to acquiring herd immunity.When Chris Whitty, England’s Chief Medical Officer, was asked at Thursday’s press conference what percentage of the world’s population has been infected, he put the figure at  per cent.If the true figure is between  and  per cent, the NHS can probably copewe ease off on some of the more extreme social distancing measures.Would ending the lockdown be ­gambling with people’s lives  Yes, but so will keeping it in place.Economic downturns cost lives, just as surely as viruses. During the global financial crisis of –, the suicide rate in Europe increased by . per cent. Economic recessions also cause a rise in poverty, domestic ­violence and murder.Philip Thomas, professor of risk ­management at Bristol University, has calculated thatour GDP falls by more than . per cent as a result of the lockdown, more years of le will be lost than saved.Politicians here and where have justied their cautious approach by ­saying they refuse to put a price on human le, as though the trade-off is between the lives of vulnerable people and economic growth.But the real trade-off is between the lives we might losewe end the ­lockdown tomorrow and the lives we know we will losewe keep it in place indefinitely.MPs aren’t being morally ­courageous. Rather, they’re just focusing on the next -hour news cycle, as they always do.What’s needed is a bold political leader who’s willing to risk some short-term pain to re-start the economy, thereby safeguarding all of our futures.I know of just such a person, but unfortunately he’s in hospital recovering from coronavirus.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealThe UK government’s measures to contain the coronavirus epidemic are just starting to make a ­dference.And with the three-week lockdown under review tomorrow, now is NOT the time to lt them.After a slow and indecisive start, the measures they now have put in place, including recommendations to stay at home, limiting travel, physical ­distancing, banning large gatherings and shutting shops and pubs, are just starting to show signs that they are slowing the spread of the virus.This means that there are fewer new cases, with fewer people becoming seriously sick and less demand on hospital beds, intensive care and articial ventilation.This means that the pressure on health services is reduced, which, in turn, will lead to fewer deaths from Covid- and other causes.Without the actions that have been taken and just letting the epidemic run its course, we would be likely to see more than half the population infected, and an overwhelmed health system with maybe five million hospital admissions and at least , deaths.The measures that have been taken in the UK have been of moderate strength compared to other countries.In France and Spain, the lockdown has been more severe, while in Sweden it has been less strict.The coronavirus epidemic can be thought of like a fire.If we starve a fire of oxygen, then the flames will stop and it will die down.So it is with the epidemic — reduce transmission from person to person and the number of cases will go down.Butyou let the oxygen come back too early, any embers in the fire will light up again and it will restart.So,we relax the lockdown too early, while there is still transmission of the virus going on, then the epidemic will restart.And that means that we would have wasted the efforts we have made so far.When transmission has stopped, or is at low enough levels that it can be monitored and each case and their contacts identied, isolated and treated, then the lockdown can be relaxed.We have not yet reached the peak of the epidemic, and we do not yet have the infrastructure in place for the systematic testing that will be needed to identy new cases, so now is not the time to relax the lockdown measures.Some people have talked about the serious damage done to the economy by measures the Government has put in place and the social disruption these have caused, in order to protect the public health of the nation.They have argued the lockdown will cause more harm than good in the long term. This is a  dilemma.Every le matters. Each person lost is a family member, a friend, a neighbour, a human being.They are not a number on a spreadsheet.This lockdown is the only way for us to get back on our feet.If left uncontrolled, the coronavirus by itself will cause social and economic disruption as well as damaging public health.It doesn’t need any help from politicians.It is up to us all, for the sake of ourselves, our families and our loved ones, to follow the rules, and our solidarity will allow the country totowards normal as soon as possible.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: china cash in coronavirus
story: THIS time last week, along with the rest of Fleet Street, I was writing Boris Johnson’s obituary.China had killed our Prime Minister, I said. I’ve never been so pleased to see my copy spiked.We now know from the PM himself just how close he came to death. But had things turned out dferently, my first sentence would still ring true.Boris would have paid the ultimate price for Covid-.The killer virus was spawned in China’s primitive “wet markets” and concealed by the country’s secretive communist regime and blamed by China on America and the West.Beijing’s claim of only , dead is a sick joke. The true figure could be ten times as high — or more.This, remember, is the regime that still lies about the thousands slaughtered in the  Tiananmen Square massacre.Yet China, having destroyed lives and livelihoods around the globe, is emerging as the big winner from its own pandemic.Like vultures hovering over roadkill, leaders of the world’s second-biggest economy are eyeing up the casualties of this made in-China calamity.Covid- risks opening the door to Beijing’s dominance over world trade and commerce, at unimaginable cost to our freedoms and democracy.Rattled world leaders, from Australia to Germany, are drafting emergency laws to prevent China mopping up crown jewels in pharmaceuticals, minerals, articial intelligence and robot technology.But it is probably too late. The West has turned a blind eye to China’s decades of industrial espionage and its cut-price grab for market share.Germany, Europe’s largest economy, is utterly dependent on cheap, heavily subsidised Chinese components and the VW and Mercedes car sales that account for a third of their profits.Suicidally, it will see Chinese cash as a passport out of the crisis.“We have grown too idle and too comfortable to want to do the things the Chinese do for us,” says a Cabinet insider.The world stood silent as China’s Belt And Road programme gobbled up key ports and industries, rare earth minerals and rich farmland across Africa and the Third World.Beijing is now rubbing its hands at the prospect of fresh bargains.Household-name firms here and in Europe are struggling to survive the lockdown. Some will never reopen their doors.The best might end up in Beijing at fire-sale prices.China has already seized a big stake in the UK with its richly subsidised £billion contract for the Hinkley Point nuclear power station in Somerset.Telecoms giant Huawei has its sticky fingers all over our sensitive G superhighway — a decision which must now surely be reversed.The image of communist China as a civilised equal partner is a dangerous fantasy.“China is not and never will be our friend,” a senior minister warns. “But it is the only one with ready cash and all our markets have collapsed because of something China started.“Our economy is being shattered and it is their fault. The idea of selling them some of our best companies is horrying.”China’s own economy has been hammered too. But it remains a ruthless totalitarian state which brooks no opposition.The brutal incarceration of a million Uighur Muslims in “re-education” camps is a blot on the civilised world. So is the trade in human organs from executed prisoners.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealWho will stop China becoming the world’s dominant power It will be hard for our liberal elite to swallow, but the only answer is Donald Trump.The American President has already cracked down on China’s trade and currency cheating. Democrat rival Joe Biden — backed by peace-at-any-price Barack Obama — would kowtow to Beijing.At this pivotal moment in world history, it is reassuring to know President Trump has a high regard for our Prime Minister.Once Boris is back on his feet and coronavirus begins to fade, he must join forces with the world’s greatest superpower and address the smiling menace of Chinese President Xi Jinping.As the saying goes, what doesn’t kill you makes you stronger.Boris was hardest hit, followed by chief of staff Dominic Cummings, who is only now ing to work after a fortnight in bed.A dozen others, including Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty and No Press chief Lee Cain, went down like skittles.So who was the super-spreader The finger of suspicion is pointed at health supremo Matt Hancock, first in and energetically first out of self- isolation. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus daily update dominic raab press conference
story: And the government stands before the media once again to provide the latest developments on COVID- in their bid to prevent as few more deaths as possible.Todays press conference aired at just after pm.During the week, these briefings have been held between pm and pm, while at the weekend, it is normally between pm and pm.Top ministers and government officials have been providing these updates on a daily basis since March  from  Downing Street.You can watch the governments daily press briefings by live streaming via our YouTube channel.The Suns live blog will also provide text updates from the conference today.On TV, you can catch the briefing on BBC News, or via BBC iPlayer on your computer, mobile and tablet devices.First Secretary of State Dominic Raab chaired the meeting, alongside Chief Scientic Adviser Sir Patrick Vallance and Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty.Although Prime Minister Boris Johnson is out of hospital, he is expected to take some time to recuperate following his coronavirus battle.In recent days, NHS directors Stephen Powis and Yvonne Doyle have also joined.Raab thanked the public for staying at home despite the sacrices that the measures mean families must make.He says: “We thank you, we pay tribute to you, and we are immensely proud of all youre doing”.Raab thanked the public for their sacrices over the weekend, choosing to stay inside despite the warm weather.He adds: “The overwhelming majority of people stayed at home and understood the importance of doing so.”He asked people to keep following the guidance to protect the NHS - title: large wildcat spotted cambridgeshire fen tiger returns
story: According to legend, the Fen Tiger has been on the prowl in Cambs and beyond for more than  years, with a number of sightings reported across the county.The latest sighting was recorded near Coldhams Lane, Cambs, on Saturday where the cat was said to be as big as a fully grown Labrador.A resident who lives in the area said he believed it was looking for small animals to eat around his property.He added that the cat had visited in the past, but this time he was able to capture it on camera.He told Cambridgeshire Live: It was around  or .am this morning when I saw the animal from my kitchen window.Initially I thought it was a wildcat like a Felis Silvestris, but then I went to my colleagues at the university and they said it cant have been as this animal was way bigger.The animal was a brown and black colour with a very long tail that had lots of black circles on it. The tail was so long, and its legs were thick as well with big claws.I think it somehow keeps coming to this place to hunt rabbits or other small animals.It was about the size of a fully grown Labrador dog.When asked whether or not the animal could have been the Fen Tiger the man added: I have heard about the mystery of the Fen Tiger but I dont knowthis was it.This was a wild cat like people have said the Fen Tiger is and this one is the size of a Labrador dog.The theory that Britain has an elusive population of wild big cats has proved enduring, with many people reporting sightings in rural areas.Last year, a wildcat expert revealed there had been five confirmed sightings of pumas in the UK, warning a population of around  were breeding across the country.Rick Minter, Britains leading big cat tracker, said he had seen conclusive videos of the animals amid estimates that hundreds have made the UK their home.In August, a photographer claimed to see a dog-sized cat prowling around the Yorkshire countryside.John Pearson, , was taking pictures at St Aidans Nature Reserve near Leeds when the mysterious creature caught his eye.And last April, a Labrador-sized feline was filmed prowling a field near a Cotswolds pub as police and the RSPCA told of a hamlet in Cornwall where pets have vanished is being stalked by a large panther-like animal.Several people claim to have seen the Beast of Ossett which has been spotted prowling in the woodland and fields around the West Yorkshire town.There have also been a number of alleged sightings of the Wildcat of the Wolds near Drfield, East Riding, Yorkshire, where incidents of mutilated livestock were reported as well.Back in , Lee Clford thought he had captured a photograph of a wildcat roaming the countryside near Hull.

title: eamonn holmes conspiracy 5g coronavirus
story: THIS Morning host Eamonn Holmes made jaws drop today when he suggested there could be a link between G masts and the spread of the coronavirus.Government officials have sought to debunk a widely-circulated conspiracy theory suggesting the mobile network is responsible for the virus.Despite their efforts, arsonists have torched G masts and targeted engineers around the country after the bizarre fake news spread.And today Eamonn - who co-hosts the show with his we Ruth Langsford - said he believes there could be something to the claims.He said: What I dont accept is mainstream media immediately slapping that down as not true when they dont know its not true.No one should attack or damage or do anything like that but its very easy to say it is not true because it suits the state narrative.That is all I would say as someone of an enquiring mind.Viewers took to social media to slam the presenter seconds after the segment aired.One shared an email address for the programme and encouraged others to speak of their dismay.Another said: Im guessing @thismorning do a run-through before going live, which is more worrying that they think the c**p Holmes has just spouted is factual!Others contacted Eamonn directly to complain.One wrote: This is not an enquiring mind @EamonnHolmes.You dont assume something is true until disproven, you dont spread pure opinion, you go out and look for evidence it is true or  - practically the definition of journalism. Absolutely irresponsible.But the TV host has since tweeted to say he isnt spreading  claims, adding: I reserve the right to listen and question.Celebs have been slammed for sharing the conspiracy theory.Stars like Woody Harrelson, MIA and Amir Khan have also ly linked G internet to the Covid- outbreak.Jason Gardiner and Callum Best also posted similar claims that G can impact the immune system.TV icon Amanda Holden also stirred controversy after tweeting a link to a petition to ban G.But publicists for the Britains Got Talent star later said that it was an accident – and that she doesnt believe in G conspiracies.Senior minister Michael Gove and National Medical Director of NHS England Stephen Powis have slammed the claims as complete and utter rubbish and the worst kind of fake news.Eamonn gave his opinion on the claims not long after Chris Tarrant appeared on the show to suggest the  coronavirus couldnt have started at a market in China.The Who Wants to be a Millionaire host left viewers confused after saying: I find it very hard to accept that one man in China eating a bat has caused this world scale of chaos.I find it very hard to believe. title: mum nurse shop aldi boys lockdown
story: A SINGLE mum who works as a nurse was told she couldnt go shopping at Aldi - because she had her seven-year-old twin sons with her.Victoria Astley, , had already spent half-an-hour in a queue for the store in Fenton, Stoke-on-Trent when she was refused entry by a security guard.The officer told her she couldnt go inside because she was with her sons Harvey and Joseph - and the supermarket only allows in one child at a time.Now bosses at the store have apologised to the mum for the upset.Victoria initially took to Facebook to warn other single mums about the new coronavirus lockdown rules.She wrote: Just a word of warning for single mum Aldi shoppers with more than one child.After queuing for half-an-hour with my seven-year-old twin boys, we finally got to the doors when a security guard told me we werent allowed in as its only one adult with one child.I told him that Im a single parents and theres no one at home to watch the kids.Victoria was forced to put one of the twins in a trolley and leave him at the door of the supermarket.She could only shop in areas of the shop where she could see him at all times.In an interview with the Stoke Sentinel, Victoria said: Ive been off work for seven months because Ive got osteoarthritis, fibromyalgia and other chronic health conditions, so I was already feeling a bit off after queuing.We had been to Asda previously and they let us in no problem.Aldi has offered Victoria a £ voucher as a gesture of goodwill.A spokesperson said: To help with social distancing, were encouraging all customers to try to reduce the number of family members they bring with them into our stores.However, where necessary, parents can of course shop with their children and we will remind the security guards at our Fenton store of our policy.Last week, single mum Elena Sotiriou, , who lives in Upminster, Essex, accused Iceland of discriminating against one-parent families after she was told she wasnt allowed to shop with her two young children.

title: breast pumps converted ventilators coronavirus
story: BREAST pumps are being converted into ventilators for coronavirus patients to combat shortages.Engineers in the US came up with the idea of using the machines, which are used to pull milk from a womans breast, into le-saving breathing devices.The team from Maryland have already built a few prototypes and say - with all the parts - it costs about  .Thats compared with about with the ,to ,price tag for a hospital-grade ventilator, according to SILive.Ventilators work by taking over a patients breathingwhile they are sedated, pushing air into the lungs and giving time to fight the infection and recover.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.One of the advantages of using breast pumps is that they’re built to medical standards, and have a closed-loop compressor that avoids getting contaminated as tubing only needs to be replaced between patients.Software engineer Rachel Labatt told WMAR news she came up with the idea after the US Food and Drug Administration approved the emergency use of medical devices, including positive pressure devices.After a conversation with another engineer friend, Brandi Gerstner, they used their old breast pumps to try it out.Brandi took an X-Acto kne and a screwdriver to reverse the pump’s suctionso it expels air, rather than taking it in, reports WBALTV.She even rigged the breathing instrument so that it pumps air in accordance with medical oxygen intake standards.Electrical engineer Alex Scott, who is also part of the project, said that they also soldered on a few pins onto the control board to turn it on and off.The team are working with certied pulmonologists to get the green light from the FDA so they can start putting the retrofitted respirators in hospitals.Before they’re patient-ready, however, the breath pumps will need to be outfitted with a circuit board and emergency sensors to ensure consistent air flow.Not to mention “making sure that their units in their final form are going to be sanitisable,” Brandi told WBALTV.Rachel added: “Our end goal is to get ventilators to hospitals to save patients.Writing on the teams Facebook page, Brandi said: “Safety is our first and primary focus, so please stay tuned for updates to safety data, and please let us knowyou are an engineer or doctor who has time to help review our design documentation.“Everything is open source. We are non-profit engineers looking to make a dference.”It comes as engineers around the globe race to meet the demand of ventilators needed due to the pandemic.Downing Street had also called for UK manufacturers and suppliers to help boosts stocks, with firms including Dyson, Rolls-Royce and Mercedes Formula One team now involved in the efforts to produce more.Last week, Health Secretary Matt Hancock has said the NHS is expecting to take delivery of  new ventilators amid the Covid- outbreak.The Government also announced that  new ventilators would be supplied to hospitals next week, although it is thought the NHS needs at least , devices to cope with peak demand.It already has , in hospitals, with another , ordered.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dominic raab daily press conference
story: BRITAIN#S lockdown will not be lted this week, Dominic Raab confirmed today.The First Secretary of State said that top officials would look at the evidence this week, but he did not expect anything to change in the coming days.The evidence suggests that Britain is still going through the peak of the virus, and the death rate will continue to go up for days to come.Taking the Downing Street press conference this evening, he said that the lockdown had been a success over the Easter bank holiday weekend, despite police having to take action to stop Brits flocking to parks in some areas to soak up the sun.He said: #This week SAGEwill review the measures.He said it was #far too early# to talk about how to lt the lockdown and any talk about relaxing rules would be #getting ahead of ourselves#.SAGE are due to meet this week and look at all the lockdown evidence and how successful it#s been.But as Britain#s death numbers continue to rise by greater numbers, there are no plans to lt strict measures until they start to flatten.Mr Raab, who is still deputising for the PM while he recovers from the virus, said: #At the moment, the evidence suggests we are still going through the peak of this crisis. #It is absolutely, crucially important that we don’t take our eye off the ball##We have lost too many loved ones, made too many sacrices to give up now.#Chief Scientic Adviser Patrick Vallance said it would be a #dficult# week, and added: #We’re tracking behind Italy # so the death toll is likely to be even higher.The news comes as the number of dead in Britain leapt up again today # to more than , in total.Among the latest deaths is a -year-old nursery worker who died after catching coronavirus while waiting for a transplant in hospital.Katie Horne, from Burgess Hill, West Sussex, battled both Covid- and a liver condition for  days after the positive diagnosis meant she wasn’t able to go on the transplant list.And eight more health workers have died from the disease – bringing the total for NHS and care workers to .Meanwhile, Boris and partner Carrie Symonds have been seen walking dog Dilyn today – as the PM continues to recover from coronavirus.They are expecting their first child together in the coming weeks – and are engaged to be married. title: pensioners happy hour coronavirus
story: A group of  MPs are demanding the Government order firms to create the ‘Happy Hour’ to stave off an epidemic of isolation among over s.Lib Dem MP Jamie Stone, who is spearheading the campaign, said it is vital the elderly are helped to keep in touch with their friends and family during the lockdown.He told The Sun: “Calling elderly family and friends to see how they are is seriously important because, sadly, a lot of people are fearful right now.“Not in any way to underestimate the absolute danger of coronavirus, but all of us have a duty to cheer each other up.With two million pensioners living in poverty and so many more at risk due to this crisis, it is our responsibility as a nation to make sure we’re not isolating this vulnerable population even further.“Happy Hour calls will help older people to stay in touch with their loved ones and avoid loneliness during this global crisis.“Alleviating just this little bit of financial pressure could make all the dference to someone struggling with loneliness right now.”Mr Stone is calling for action after Judith Perham, who lives in his constituency of Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross in Scotland, got in touch with the idea.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealShe said: I know I’m probably one of the lucky ones to be able to use some of - not all of the modern technology - but l also know there are an awful lot of us older generation that don’t.I think that giving some sort of free time on the phone would be of a benefit to them in order to contact family, who might also be experiencing financial hardship at this time and trying to be careful with money.“This is especially important when living in a rural area as we do in the far north of Scotland.We all need to be looking out for each other at this time and,this achieves a result, then l know that with your help we have helped someone somewhere.The letter to Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden urges him to “continue to do all you can to help the most isolated vulnerable people during this health crisis”.Some  MPs, including Lib Dem, Labour and Tory politicians, have signed the letter.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: angela merkel coronavirus lockdown germany
story: ANGELA Merkel is under pressure to reopen schools and factories this week after violence erupted in a backlash at lockdown measures.The Chancellor is set to rule on whether to extend restrictions as the number of coronavirus deaths in the country continued to fall.Germany reported , new confirmed Covid- cases today, marking the third consecutive day of decline, and the  deaths was also the third daily fall.The encouraging stats emerged after reports of thugs attacking police who were enforcing social distancing rules.One group in Frankfurt attacked cops with iron bars when they tried to disperse the crowd.Another group of  attacked an officer with stones and roof tiles and iron bars, Deutsche Welle reported.Germany has weathered the pandemic better than Italy, Spain, France and the UK where the death toll is much higher.But its industrial powerhouse economy is set to take a heavy blow as it is reliant on exports which have fallen drastically.Regional politicians are due to meet Mrs Merkel on Wednesday to discuss a path out of the lockdown, which is in place until at least April .The Chancellor has said the decision will be guided by recommendations from the National Academy of Sciences Leopoldina.It delivered a report today suggesting schools should reopen as soon as possible, starting with primary and middle schools, although it said nurseries should stay closed.Scientists also recommended reopening shops and restaurants as long as social distancing measures are rigorously respected, and for government offices to get back to work.The head of the Academy, Gerald Haug, said this could only happen along with by an obligation to wear face masks on public transport to prevent a second wave of infections.He said: Every citizen should in the future have this type of protection for their mouth and nose and wear it each time social distancing measures cant be respected, he Der Spiegel.Armin Laschet, the conservative governor of North Rhine-Westphalia, called for a responsibleto normalcy.He said small retailers could potentially reopen following the model in place for bakeries with only two customers at a time.Dietmar Woidke, governor of Brandenburg, called for a more cautious approach to avoid the risk of undoing the gains Germany has made in combating the virus.Germanys economy is forecast to shrink by . per cent in the second quarter of , the biggest decline since records began in  and more than double the fall in the  global crash.It has so far recorded almost , Covid- cases but only , deaths.Our journalists strive Mr Bates, a mechanic for Toyota, old Mail Online: People are still not taking this outbreak seriously and that upsets me. I take it personally. There was a picture Iaposve seen of a beach where there was an ice cream hut open with people queuing outside like it was a normal day. It horries me that people still are not sticking to the lockdown measures. It does upset both of us. Mrs Bates wrote on Facebook : All I’m seeing lately is jokes about coronavirus. I understand humour is very important to keep you going through this hard time but please think about those people it does effect.Our little girl has lung and heart disease and floppy airways and is still currently sitting in intensive care,our little girl catches this virus she won’t be as lucky to fight it. The anxiety every time a new nurse or doctor comes into our bay is getting unbearable. And the simplest things like going to get a drink downstairs now scares me so much so that I don’t and I isolate myself so I don’t have to come into contact with anyone just to keep my little girl alive. So please people before posting jokes and silly comments please think about who might see or read it, as some of us are living in this nightmare and are going to find these months extremely dficult. In another Facebook post she wrote: Both myself and Wayne are utterly heartbroken yet again that we are in a position where we may lose our little girlshe doesnapost carry on fighting. Please, please, please keep Erin in your prayers. We canapost lose her over this virus. She has battled through too much – we need her, she completes us.  I hope that those who havenapost taken this virus serious read this and I hope it now sinks in. Mr Bates said that when Erin was born, he and his we had been told they might not be able to have children so were aposover the moonapos after trying to start a family for  years. But their daughteraposs first six months have been an emotional rollercoaster as she was diagnosed with a catalogue of medical conditions including a heart condition that meant she had open heart surgery in December. In January, she also suffered a respiratory virus, which causes a potentially fatal bout of bronchiolitis and pneumonia in babies. Erin also suffered tracheomalacia and bronchomalacia which affected her her windpipe and its branches into the lungs, and already required use of the CPAP machine. She is currently in a stable condition and her parents have thanked the dedicated NHS workers at the hospital. The family have received messages of support from well-wishers on Facebook.

story: NewsGran, , who vanished found dead by murder detectives under plastic sheetWendy Morse was reported missing on Mothers Day and her body was later found by police in a conservatory at her North Staffordshire homeShareCommentsByRuby DaviesSam Elliott:,  APR NewsThe tragic -year-old grandmother was found with severe head injuries " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPolice discovered the body of missing grandmother Wendy Morse covered by a sheet in her conservatory, an inquest has heard. A murder investigation has been launched after the -year-old grandmother was found at her Staffordshire home. She had been reported missing by concerned relatives on Motheraposs Day and officers later broke into her home and made a chilling discovery. Police said that the retired midwe had a severe blunt trauma head injury. More details of the her death emerged as an inquest was opened and adjourned at North Staffordshire Coroneraposs Court. It comes as police secured a European Arrest Warrant as part of their attempts to extradite a -year-old man from Sweden. They say they want to speak to the man in connection with her death. The inquest was told how Wendy had been reported missing by her daughter on Sunday, March  after she failed to get any response when she knocked on the door of her Tunstall Road home. Police soon broke in and made the terrible discovery.  North Staffordshire assistant coroner Sarah Murphy said: The circumstances reported to the coroneraposs court are that the deceased lived alone and was having building work done at the house. She was not satisfied with the builder and another contractor was due to start. On March  via social media she last had contact with her family. Her daughter later sent her a message but it was not replied to. Her daughter became concerned and visited her on March . There was no reply to her knocking on the door and she found flowers on the doorstep sent by her brother. She became concerned and contacted the police and reported the deceased as a missing person.  Police arrived and checked the property and while at the back they noticed a curtain hanging from the window of the conservatory. They saw there was furniture covered and on the floor it looked like there was a body covered in plastic sheeting. They found the deceased on the floor in the conservatory. The deceased had a severe blunt trauma head injury. There were signs of a disturbance as there was glass and a bottle smashed on the floor. We donapost have a cause of death. A post-mortem examination has been requested and there is reason to suspect that the death was violent and unnatural and therefore an inquest is necessary.

The camper from Hull travelled  miles to North Wales before he was approached by a -year-old local. The man then brandished a stick after he had been told to leave. The video was posted on social media after the camper was confronted by a group of locals who asked him to leave the site at Llyn Cowlyd near Trefriw on Saturday, Hull Live reports. Locals spotted two campers at the site, with one claiming to be from Hull, and asked them to leave after reminding them of the rules of the lockdown. The Hull man reacted angrily, slipping on the grass as he rushed towards the -year-old dad before picking up a large stick and swinging it down towards his head. Then the man threatened to hit my dad in the head with the stick. She added: When the police arrived, the campers said they were from Hull. The officers were mortied.  They were fined and they traced the number plate to make sure they ed home. Her dad added: It was unbelievable that they travelled all the way from Hull to the top of a mountain to camp when the whole country is on lockdown and the government clearly has instructed everyone to stay home unless necessary. They were asked to move the night before and were told they weren’t supposed to be there, but they decided to ignore that and the police had been informed. The police arrived the following morning and dealt with the situation.  The manaposs daughter also posted a follow-up tweet showing the mess she claimed the campers made before they were moved on by police. The picture shows rubbish strewn across the site including bottles of Coke and water, tin foil, toilet roll and a burning fire. She tweeted: “Also this is the mess they left on our neighbouraposs land. Absolute disgrace. “The police did eventually arrive and dealt with the matter, him and his mate will hopefully think twice before leaving their house again.”  The video has had more than , views on Twitter and has been shared almost , times. He does not represent my our city. Please apologise to your father on behalf of the city of Kingston Upon Hull.” The campers ignored Government advice to avoid temptation to visit the UK’s beauty spots during Easter.
